Bug.Summery: Error has occured after update

Stacktrace.Reason: Internal Error in the OSGi framework. Please report this problem.

Bug.Summery: Switching between Config types breaks common tab layout
Bug.WithStack:
With latest from HEAD Select a Java Application Launch Config Select Common Tab Select an Eclipse Application launch Config (Common Tab should stay selected)
-> Display in favorites widget gets incorrectly resized (smaller) The problem occurs whenever the Common Tab is visible before it is initialized. The Display in Favorites widget does not have its input set yet, and is unable to calculate an appropriate size. May need to enforce a fixed, or minimum size on the widget *** Bug 80680 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** No longer happens in I20050315-1100 *** Bug 102275 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
Bug.WithOutStack:
With latest from HEAD Select a Java Application Launch Config Select Common Tab Select an Eclipse Application launch Config (Common Tab should stay selected)
-> Display in favorites widget gets incorrectly resized (smaller) The problem occurs whenever the Common Tab is visible before it is initialized. The Display in Favorites widget does not have its input set yet, and is unable to calculate an appropriate size. May need to enforce a fixed, or minimum size on the widget *** Bug 80680 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** No longer happens in I20050315-1100 *** Bug 102275 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Bug.Summery: SWT should support responsiveness debugging
Bug.WithStack:
A long time ago, I got in the habit of instrumenting EventTable so that I could track down responsiveness problems. The idea is that if a listener takes too long to process an event, then it should be noted.
Unfortunately, this isn't a permanent feature in SWT, so it is hard for others to use this technique. They either have to know what code to change, or find and apply a patch to SWT.
I'm proposing a mechanism similar to the current debug flags that Platform UI uses. This way, we could hook it up to the tracing options mechanism. This way, turning on this kind of debugging is as easy as modifying a launch configuration.
I'll attach a patch. Created attachment 16134 Patch to "org.eclipse.swt"
The creation of PRETTY_PRINT_NAMES table in EventTable is perhaps overkill. It's nice because people who don't know SWT intimately (like me) don't tend to know the event type constants by heart. If you don't want this, then it could be removed and only the numeric event type printed. (You need to know the event type so you know which method on a SWTEventListener is going to be called by TypedListener.) Created attachment 16135 Patch to "org.eclipse.ui"
Adds two options to the ".options" file. Created attachment 16136 Patch to "org.eclipse.ui.workbench"
Takes the two options and pushes them into SWT display when we create it. If SWT applies this patch, then could you please punt the bug back to Platform UI when you're done? (So we can apply our patches....) Looks interesting. Patching the event table will only gather statistics for untyped Listeners. Perhaps a standard typed listener collection class should be added and used by the custom controls and the other components of SWT. This class could also be instrumented.
VI, SN and SSQ to evaluate the patch to figure out how this kind of functionality can be embedded in SWT. This would make a big difference to the performance instrumentation that we are going to turn on during M6 and M7. We have noticed some Java editor operations taking a long time on keystrokes and we need to investigate them. Adding my name to the cc list as we are now tracking performance issues more closely. Please remove the performance keyword if this is not a performance bug.
It's a good idea that fell off a cliff. Since it involves API, we can't really make changes for 3.1 ... however, we might be able to make available patched versions of these classes for performance work by attaching them to this bug report in the same way that Doug has done.
My thinking in the long term is to add API to all filters to run either before or after an event, rather than add custom profiling API. An application that is interested in profiling would hook both filters and maintain a stack. Re comment #8: "Since it involves API, we can't really make changes for 3.1"
Changes that add new, non-breaking API, specifically to fix performance issues, can still be made with the approval of one PMC team member.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of bug 360052 ***

Bug.Summery: allow running more than one test case per session
Bug.WithStack:
The session test framework runs a single test case per session. This is usually what we want, but there are cases when we want to hole a bunch of test cases in the same session. For instance, running a test suite with some command line option, and then running it again without that command line option. Running every single test case as a separate session just makes it take longer and brings no value.
An acceptable implementation would be that this set of test cases would be made of all test cases found in a given class. The changes required to support that are not trivial. Won't fix any soon. This actually got fixed recently.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 104517 ***
Bug.WithOutStack:

Bug.Summery: background source lookup
Bug.WithStack: While investigating bug 79450, I realized that source lookup should also be performed in the background to avoid blocking the UI thread. Created attachment 16153 patch Fixed in LaunchView. Source lookup and source display are now separated into jobs - the source lookup occurrs in a non UI thread to avoid blocking during the search, and the display (openning editor) occurrs in a UI Job. Please verify, Jared. Verified.
Bug.WithOutStack: While investigating bug 79450, I realized that source lookup should also be performed in the background to avoid blocking the UI thread. Created attachment 16153 patch Fixed in LaunchView. Source lookup and source display are now separated into jobs - the source lookup occurrs in a non UI thread to avoid blocking during the search, and the display (openning editor) occurrs in a UI Job. Please verify, Jared. Verified.

Bug.Summery: Rename the "Attach - Java Process" launch config type
Bug.WithStack: This name doesn't fit well with the rest of the launch configuration types. The way all the Eclipse types are named is as a noun, i.e. the thing we're profiling. But here, we're not profiling an "Attach - Java Process", we're profiling a running application. I would suggest the name "Running Java Application", just like the debugger has. Although, these two are incompatible and shouldn't be shared among modes. Any thoughts Eugene/Valentina ? This is a tough one. It is hard to tie/rename "Attach" into a "Launch" action actually. Profile a "running java application" sounds okay to me. As a note, downstream product contains an "Attach to a Running Process" entry in the debug launcher. If we stick with the terminology here then less confusion to users. I agree.. we should be consistent with the debugger. Deferring from 4.1 as per the official 4.1 enhancement plan. http://eclipse.org/tptp/home/project_info/featureplans/features.php?source=All&project=All&release=4.1&file=TPTPFeatures_4.1.xml Setting to next release. Setting target to future so it doesn't show up in 4.2 feature query. As of TPTP 4.6.0, TPTP is in maintenance mode and focusing on improving quality by resolving relevant defects and increasing test coverage through test creation, automation, Build Verification Tests (BVTs), and expanded run-time execution. As such, TPTP is not delivering enhancements. As part of the TPTP Bugzilla housecleaning process (see http://wiki.eclipse.org/Bugzilla_Housecleaning_Processes), this enhancement is resolved as WONTFIX. For this enhancement to be considered, please re-open with an attached patch including the Description Document (see http://www.eclipse.org/tptp/home/documents/process/development/description_documents.html), code (see http://www.eclipse.org/tptp/home/documents/resources/TPTPDevGuide.htm), and test cases (see http://www.eclipse.org/tptp/home/documents/process/TPTP_Testing_Strategy.html). As such, TPTP is not delivering enhancements. For this enhancement to be considered, please re-open with an attached patch including the Description Document (see http://www.eclipse.org/tptp/home/documents/process/development/description_documents.html), code (see http://www.eclipse.org/tptp/home/documents/resources/TPTPDevGuide.htm), and test cases (see http://www.eclipse.org/tptp/home/documents/process/TPTP_Testing_Strategy.html). Bug.Summery: [1.5] Extract Method must not generate return type with type variable [refactoring][1.5]
[JUnit] Internal error occured during "Launch" with JUnit

Stacktrace.Reason: Couldn't get test harness for name org.eclipse.jdt.junit.testprioritization.DefaultTestPrioritizer

Bug.WithStack:
While trying to do the example from http://www.onjava.com/pub/a/onjava/2004/02/04/juie.html , I always get the following error: An internal error occurred during: "Launch".
I'm using Eclipse 3.1 and JUnit 3.8.1
Here's my .log: !MESSAGE An internal error occurred during: "Launching". !STACK 0 java.lang.RuntimeException: Couldn't get test harness for name org.eclipse.jdt.junit.testprioritization.DefaultTestPrioritizer at org.eclipse.jdt.junit.TestManipulatorManager.getPrioritizationBundle(TestManipulatorManager.java:163) at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.junit.launcher.JUnitLaunchConfiguration.createClassPath(JUnitLaunchConfiguration.java:214) at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.junit.launcher.JUnitLaunchConfiguration.createVMRunner(JUnitLaunchConfiguration.java:75) at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.junit.launcher.JUnitBaseLaunchConfiguration.launchTypes(JUnitBaseLaunchConfiguration.java:157) at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.junit.launcher.JUnitBaseLaunchConfiguration.launch(JUnitBaseLaunchConfiguration.java:131) at org.eclipse.debug.internal.core.LaunchConfiguration.launch(LaunchConfiguration.java:569) at org.eclipse.debug.internal.ui.DebugUIPlugin.buildAndLaunch(DebugUIPlugin.java:732) at org.eclipse.debug.internal.ui.DebugUIPlugin$6.run(DebugUIPlugin.java:904) at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:66) Move to JDT/UI Sorry, I didn't make it clear: the error not only occurrs in the above mentioned example but also everytime I try to make a test in JUnit is this a standard eclipse installation? I couldn't find a class 'org.eclipse.jdt.junit.TestManipulatorManager' The only thing I did was installing some Plugins(PHPeclipse, JFacedDB, Omondo) and the mentioned JUnit in my Java-lib-directory.
And strangely, neither can I find the 'org.eclipse.jdt.junit.TestManipulatorManager' class. Maybe however, I looked in the wrong place (Eclipse-Plugin-Dir, org.eclipse.jdt.* subdirs)? you must also have installed the continuous testing plug-ins, these plug-ins replace jdt.junit. Recommend to report the bug report there. That's it. Although I can't remember it, I must have installed these plug-ins. After deleting them, it finally works.
Bug.WithOutStack:
While trying to do the example from http://www.onjava.com/pub/a/onjava/2004/02/04/juie.html , I always get the following error: An internal error occurred during: "Launch".
I'm using Eclipse 3.1 and JUnit 3.8.1
Here's my .log: !MESSAGE An internal error occurred during: "Launching". !STACK 0
Move to JDT/UI Sorry, I didn't make it clear: the error not only occurrs in the above mentioned example but also everytime I try to make a test in JUnit is this a standard eclipse installation? I couldn't find a class 'org.eclipse.jdt.junit.TestManipulatorManager' The only thing I did was installing some Plugins(PHPeclipse, JFacedDB, Omondo) and the mentioned JUnit in my Java-lib-directory.
And strangely, neither can I find the 'org.eclipse.jdt.junit.TestManipulatorManager' class. Maybe however, I looked in the wrong place (Eclipse-Plugin-Dir, org.eclipse.jdt.* subdirs)? you must also have installed the continuous testing plug-ins, these plug-ins replace jdt.junit. Recommend to report the bug report there. That's it. Although I can't remember it, I must have installed these plug-ins. After deleting them, it finally works.

Are you sure about the Eclipse version? And have you talked to Silenio about this? I'm sure of the GTK+ version. Note that the UI was not blocked and was able to respond to expose and resize events, so I do not think this is an SWT problem. Do you remember having cancelled the OpenType dialog opening prior to hanging ? No, I don't recall having done that. I cannot reproduce using GTK+2.2.1 and last integration build I200411240800. Billy, have you seen this hang recently ? If you have, do you have anything related to indexing in your .log file ? I am able to reproduce this one.
Make sure you start up Eclipse with a *closed* Java project. After startup, open the project and then Open Type. The progress dialog will be there forever. The Cancel button is active though.
Before the Open Type works again, I have to rebuild the project and restart Eclipse.
Ringo Forgot to mention:
Eclipse 3.1M3 on Windows 2000 with JDK 1.4.2_05. I am still running M3 since post-M3 builds annoy me due to Bug 73969.
Ringo Has the JDT Core team managed to reproduce the problem using the steps given by Ringo?
Note: If it is taking a long time to open, then it's a performance problem. If it *hangs* (i.e. never opens) then it's a bug whose priority should probably be raised. I doubt we can reproduce this PR using HEAD since the AllTypesCache was removed last week. Time spent in scenario described by Ringo is to index files of the reopened project(s).
Here are times noticed on an Eclipse 3.1 full source workspace (86 projects): 1) Close all projects: ~45s 2) Open all projects: ~7 s 3) Index all files (~10600): ~30s
So, time to index all files sounds definitely reasonable...
Moreover, this scenario should happen seldom as user does not close/open often big projects and even if it happens, indexing progress is shown to user in dialog. So, he cannot longer feel that eclipse is currently hanging.
Due to all these reasons, I close this bug as FIXED. Re: "Close all projects: ~45s" Just out of curiosity, why does it take 45 seconds to *close* all the projects. If the projects are all closed, then there should be nothing to index. It seems like it should be almost instant. Mike, I didn't say that index take 45s while closing project. AFAIK, there's no indexing during this operation. I put this time just to make indexing time relative to other operations on same number of projects... Apologies Fred. I misread.
Adding JA to CC list to answer the question: Why does closing all projects take 45s? I have entered Bug 94436 to investigate performance of closing projects. This does have to do significant work, since it saves the project subtree to disk. Other PRE_CLOSE resource change listeners might also be adding some time. Verified for 3.1 M7 using build I20050509-2010 + jdt.core HEAD.

Are you sure about the Eclipse version? And have you talked to Silenio about this? I'm sure of the GTK+ version. Note that the UI was not blocked and was able to respond to expose and resize events, so I do not think this is an SWT problem. Do you remember having cancelled the OpenType dialog opening prior to hanging ? No, I don't recall having done that. I cannot reproduce using GTK+2.2.1 and last integration build I200411240800. Billy, have you seen this hang recently ? If you have, do you have anything related to indexing in your .log file ? I am able to reproduce this one.
Make sure you start up Eclipse with a *closed* Java project. After startup, open the project and then Open Type. The progress dialog will be there forever. The Cancel button is active though.
Before the Open Type works again, I have to rebuild the project and restart Eclipse.
Ringo Forgot to mention:
Eclipse 3.1M3 on Windows 2000 with JDK 1.4.2_05. I am still running M3 since post-M3 builds annoy me due to Bug 73969.
Ringo Has the JDT Core team managed to reproduce the problem using the steps given by Ringo?
Note: If it is taking a long time to open, then it's a performance problem. If it *hangs* (i.e. never opens) then it's a bug whose priority should probably be raised. I doubt we can reproduce this PR using HEAD since the AllTypesCache was removed last week. Time spent in scenario described by Ringo is to index files of the reopened project(s).
Here are times noticed on an Eclipse 3.1 full source workspace (86 projects): 1) Close all projects: ~45s 2) Open all projects: ~7 s 3) Index all files (~10600): ~30s
So, time to index all files sounds definitely reasonable...
Moreover, this scenario should happen seldom as user does not close/open often big projects and even if it happens, indexing progress is shown to user in dialog. So, he cannot longer feel that eclipse is currently hanging.
Due to all these reasons, I close this bug as FIXED. Re: "Close all projects: ~45s" Just out of curiosity, why does it take 45 seconds to *close* all the projects. If the projects are all closed, then there should be nothing to index. It seems like it should be almost instant. Mike, I didn't say that index take 45s while closing project. AFAIK, there's no indexing during this operation. I put this time just to make indexing time relative to other operations on same number of projects... Apologies Fred. I misread.
Adding JA to CC list to answer the question: Why does closing all projects take 45s? I have entered Bug 94436 to investigate performance of closing projects. This does have to do significant work, since it saves the project subtree to disk. Other PRE_CLOSE resource change listeners might also be adding some time. Verified for 3.1 M7 using build I20050509-2010 + jdt.core HEAD.

Bug.Summery: [other] EclipseLog does not follow Eclipse log format
Bug.WithStack:
i2004124
I realized that EclipseLog does not know about severity or error code, which are part of Eclipse's log format. It is then up to the clients to provide that information as part of the "entry" string (ensuring the format is correct).
The result is that clients going directly to the FrameworkLog API (such as the framework itself and update.configurator) generate log entries that do not conform to the expected format, so PDE's log viewer ends up having problems to parse the file (cannot parse the date, for instance).
Here is an !ENTRY line for a log entry generated by the framework:
!ENTRY org.eclipse.osgi 2004-11-25 10:55:43.378
Here is an !ENTRY line for a log entry generated by an Eclipse plug-in:
!ENTRY org.eclipse.ui.ide 4 4 2004-11-24 11:15:37.429
I cannot think of any nice fix for this that does not involve adding "severity" and "error code" to FrameworkLogEntry. I suspect that this is why it does not know about severity or error code. A stupid proposition/question, why could not we automatically add two random values to the message when logged by the framework log?
That would require every client to be changed to prepend a "0 0 " string to the log entry message. Or we could check in the log implementation whether the log entry message starts with two numbers, and add "0 " strings if needed. Either way, I don't like these solutions very much (comparing to adding the two fields to FrameworkLogEntry or a subclass of it). Moving confirmed bugs/enhancements out of the "inbox" Tom, this looks like a dup of bug 123189 that you just fixed? yup, this is a dup. Thanks John.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 123189 ***

Bug.Summery: [Dialogs] Open Resource could allow for select/deselect projects
Bug.WithStack:
I often work in 3 branchs of the same project at the same time. Using ctrl-shift-r to open files in quite handy but it would be nice if I could de-select projects that files will be listed from. If a list of projects with checkboxes on the open resource dialog appears and I could select/unselect open projects and it would remember which ones were selected that would be very helpful. I believe this can already be accomplished via working sets...Tod? As they are the same project I think this is a lot tougher to do - you can always set working sets on a set of projects. The same functionality does exist in working sets _but_ if I have four projects and I need all possible permutations of those four projects listed then it is quite complicated to create that set of working sets and select/unselect them.
Let's take my example of four projects (a,b,c,d). If I want the open-resources to only open resources from a and d then I need a working set of projects a and d. Now my math is a little rusty but all permutations of abcd is going to be at least 6 working sets (ab, ac, ad, bc, bd, cd).
Those 6 working sets are also going to be a lot harder to select and use - ignoring the creation aspect anytime my project set changes - than 4 check boxes on the open resources dialog.
moving Open Resource related bugs to Szymon. Szymon, please move between you and Krystof as needed. Let me know if you have any questions. These are all the bugs I had related to OpenResource. This can already be achieved via working sets.
Bug.WithOutStack:
I often work in 3 branchs of the same project at the same time. Using ctrl-shift-r to open files in quite handy but it would be nice if I could de-select projects that files will be listed from. If a list of projects with checkboxes on the open resource dialog appears and I could select/unselect open projects and it would remember which ones were selected that would be very helpful. I believe this can already be accomplished via working sets...Tod? As they are the same project I think this is a lot tougher to do - you can always set working sets on a set of projects. The same functionality does exist in working sets _but_ if I have four projects and I need all possible permutations of those four projects listed then it is quite complicated to create that set of working sets and select/unselect them.
Let's take my example of four projects (a,b,c,d). If I want the open-resources to only open resources from a and d then I need a working set of projects a and d. Now my math is a little rusty but all permutations of abcd is going to be at least 6 working sets (ab, ac, ad, bc, bd, cd).
Those 6 working sets are also going to be a lot harder to select and use - ignoring the creation aspect anytime my project set changes - than 4 check boxes on the open resources dialog.
moving Open Resource related bugs to Szymon. Szymon, please move between you and Krystof as needed. Let me know if you have any questions. These are all the bugs I had related to OpenResource. This can already be achieved via working sets.

Bug.Summery: Allow edits of a "Log Correlation", such as adding new logs.
Bug.WithStack:
Provide UI for adding or deleting logs from an existing correlation. Correlation re- executes at OK. Drag & drop would be nice here... Christ, can you explain more on the requirement. deletion on logs under a correlation are currently support in LTA. And any re- correlation on logs actually create a new correlation. not contained in 3.3 so moving to 4.1 as P1 not contained in 4.0 moving to 4.1
Theme: simple to use Currently there is no way to rerun a correlation or update the logs information for that correlation. The user has to create a new correlation with the same information in order to recorrelate the data. The requirement is to be able to update existing correlation by adding or removing logs. A Properties popup action or double click on the selected correlation should open the existing 'Create New Correlation wizard', with fields updated based on selected correlation ( see screencap below ).The user can update the correlation information ( correlation name, add/remove logs, change the correlation type ), then finish the wizard. At this point, selected logs are recorrelated based on selected correlation type. correlation = association in TPTP Changing to P1 as per the 4.1 official plan. To be reassigned once the resources will be committed Function implemented
To rename or upadte the content for a log correlation, select the correlation in the Log Navigator view and use the Properties popup menu action As of TPTP 4.6.0, TPTP is in maintenance mode and focusing on improving quality by resolving relevant enhancements/defects and increasing test coverage through test creation, automation, Build Verification Tests (BVTs), and expanded run-time execution. As part of the TPTP Bugzilla housecleaning process (see http://wiki.eclipse.org/Bugzilla_Housecleaning_Processes), this enhancement/defect is verified/closed by the Project Lead since this enhancement/defect has been resolved and unverified for more than 1 year and considered to be fixed. If this enhancement/defect is still unresolved and reproducible in the latest TPTP release (http://www.eclipse.org/tptp/home/downloads/), please re-open.

Bug.Summery: Allow to refresh log correlations with the updated log entries
Bug.WithStack: Provide functionality to refresh existing correlations in the UI as an action in the menu. The action will synchronize the logs content part of the correlation with the latest content received in the workbench and redo the correlation. Contact Eric Labadie for details. not contained in 3.3 so moving to 4.1 as P1 moving to 4.1 not contained in 4.0 ased on the correlation implementation, recorrelate can resume from the last correlated event. It is up to the correlation implementation to do that. Simple correlations, such as Base Time correlation, shold be able to resume correlation from the last correlated events since events are logged in ordered by time Changing to P1 as per the 4.1 official plan. To be reassigned once the resources will be committed committed; defect 106253 still needs to be integrated by 08/19 As of TPTP 4.6.0, TPTP is in maintenance mode and focusing on improving quality by resolving relevant enhancements/defects and increasing test coverage through test creation, automation, Build Verification Tests (BVTs), and expanded run-time execution. Bug.Summery: Clean up warnings (most, not all) in org.eclipse.wst.ws.parser
Bug.WithStack:
The patch I will be attaching removes the use of IPluginDescriptor from ParserPlugin and also some unused imports in a some other classes. Created attachment 16142 This patch cleans up most of the warnings in org.eclipse.wst.ws.parser Beware the duplicate content in the downloaded patch! After downloading the patch, you'll have to manually delete the duplicate content that's being inserted (everything including and after "Content-Type: text/plain").
Jeff Liu is opening a bugzilla for this. Patch committed. Thanks - CB. Verified.

Richard:
What is your system? AMD64, Xeon, IA_64? Which SWT build are you using? (Linux GTK AMD64?) Your JVM appears to be Sun 1.5 AMD64. amd64
I think I'm using the 64-bit swt build ... the .so libraries that are packaged with azureus have a 3106 tag on the end (if that indicates version number at all for you).
And yes, the JVM is Sun 1.5 amd64 64 bit crash - possibly another vararg problem?
void g_object_set (gpointer object, const gchar *first_property_name, ...);
Ouch, maybe. We don't set any floats though... I'll try to see if I can reproduce it. This will only happen when someone has set a per-row property in a table (foreground, background, font)... Increasing the severity. This bug kind of got forgotten but it must be looked at before 3.1. Ok, it's before 3.1. Any more on it? I did a bunch of tests on our x86-64 machine and made sure the code from the stack trace got hit. I saw no crashes. The code has somewhat changed since when the bug was filed, so maybe this has been fixed already.
I am going to mark this as WORKSFORME. Please re-open if you still see crashes like this using 3.1RC3 or newer.
Bug.WithOutStack:
The crash occurs in Azureus, once a torrent has been "checked". I first presented them with the bug, but based on the log output (below) from "java", the crash was in the SWT code and I was told to report the bug here. Below is the log generated by jre 1.5.0.
http://thebeever.com/~baver/azureus.log
(rather long, so not included here). Pasting log info for further reference.

Richard:
What is your system? AMD64, Xeon, IA_64? Which SWT build are you using? (Linux GTK AMD64?) Your JVM appears to be Sun 1.5 AMD64. amd64
I think I'm using the 64-bit swt build ... the .so libraries that are packaged with azureus have a 3106 tag on the end (if that indicates version number at all for you).
And yes, the JVM is Sun 1.5 amd64 64 bit crash - possibly another vararg problem?
void g_object_set (gpointer object, const gchar *first_property_name, ...);
Ouch, maybe. We don't set any floats though... I'll try to see if I can reproduce it. This will only happen when someone has set a per-row property in a table (foreground, background, font)... Increasing the severity. This bug kind of got forgotten but it must be looked at before 3.1. Ok, it's before 3.1. Any more on it? I did a bunch of tests on our x86-64 machine and made sure the code from the stack trace got hit. I saw no crashes. The code has somewhat changed since when the bug was filed, so maybe this has been fixed already.
I am going to mark this as WORKSFORME. Please re-open if you still see crashes like this using 3.1RC3 or newer.

Bug.Summery: org.eclipse.swt.gtk* build.xml gather.bin.parts target needs to collect libraries from archictecture specific directories to support source builds
Bug.WithStack:
The build.xml for org.eclipse.gtk*'s build.xml for the gather.bin.parts target needs to incorporate collecting swt libraries that are compiled during a source build. To accommodate this, I think we need to add the ${arch} value to the lines starting with * below
<target name="gather.bin.parts" depends="init" if="destination.temp.folder"> <mkdir dir="${destination.temp.folder}/${full.name}/ws/gtk"/> <copy file="${build.result.folder}/ws/gtk/swt-pi.jar" todir="${destination.temp.folder}/${full.name}/ws/gtk"/> <copy file="${build.result.folder}/ws/gtk/swt-mozilla.jar" todir="${destination.temp.folder}/${full.name}/ws/gtk"/> <copy file="${build.result.folder}/ws/gtk/swt.jar" todir="${destination.temp.folder}/${full.name}/ws/gtk"/> <copy todir="${destination.temp.folder}/${full.name}"> <fileset dir="${basedir}" *includes="fragment.properties,fragment.xml,about.html,lgpl-v21.txt,mpl-v11.txt,cpl-v10.html,os/${os}/${arch}/,META-INF/"/> </copy> <chmod perm="755" *dir="${destination.temp.folder}/${full.name}/os/${os}/${arch}" includes="**/*.so*" /> </target> Chrix to decode. The build process is utter magic to me. i believe this was just done with Kim this afternoon. One of the problem with the build last night was that in the org.eclipse.swt.gtk* script changes this line was missing a slash after arch
*includes="fragment.properties,fragment.xml,about.html,lgpl-v21.txt,mpl-v11.txt,cpl-v10.html,os/${os}/${arch},META-INF/"/>
so the current os/${os}/${arch}
should be os/${os}/${arch}/
We modified this our our build machine and the build completed without a problem.
This exposed a problem where the org.eclipse.rcp feature.xml had both gtk and gtk64 fragments for the amd64 drop which we have fixed.
Please let me know when it is completed so I can run a test build and ensure that there are not any problems for tonight :-)
released in head for both gtk and gtk64 fragments

Bug.Summery: [java debug] Step Into Outermost method invocation

Lines.Line: a) Step Into: goes into getName()
b) Step Over: goes to next line
c) Step Into Selection / Step Into Outermost: goes into doRealStuff(..)
Marking as later. May consider in a later milestone, depending on resources.
1) I prefer using the keyboard, and hyperlinks can only be activated by mouse

2) It still requires me to manually point to the method name "doRealStuff" in the scenario from comment 0. After a series of Step Over (F6), the mouse cursor is usually far away from the method name. If Step Into Selection (F9 in my workspace) would just do what I need, then my next debugging step would be just 1 keystroke away - unbeatably quick and convenient.
- the selected region, or if that's empty
- the caret position, or if that's not in a method
- the next method on the selected (current) line

Yeah when I was playing with the patch it did not work over more than one line. In this case though I guess it comes down to how we want to define 'current line' do we want it to only be the current line of text or the current executable line....I felt that it should work for broken lines as well.

Bug.WithStack:
During stepwise debugging, I often encounter code patterns like this:
void doStuff(IProgressMonitor pm) { ... something= somethingElse; doRealStuff(getName(), new SubProgressMonitor(pm, 1); ... }
When I get to the call doRealStuff(..), I'm rarely interested in stepping into getName() and new SubProgressMonitor(..). Instead, the most common action is to manually place the caret into the outermost method doRealStuff and invoke Run > Step Into Selection.
What I request is a command 'Step Into Outermost' with which I can do 'step into' without stepping into method invocations inside the outermost method invocation.
This doesn't need to be a new command - it could also be combined with Step Into Selection: When the caret is not at a place where you can step into, that action could just step into the next method invocation to the right of the current caret position. I.e. when the caret is at the beginnig of the line doRealStuff(getName(), new SubProgressMonitor(pm, 1); , I could: a) Step Into: goes into getName() b) Step Over: goes to next line c) Step Into Selection / Step Into Outermost: goes into doRealStuff(..) Marking as later. May consider in a later milestone, depending on resources. Created attachment 46628 Patch
Here's a patch that implements the requested functionality inside the Step Into Selection action. Re-openig to review patch. Not committed for 3.3. Instead we're planning on hyperlink debugging (bug 112630). Markus, can we mark this as a duplicate? Or would you still want this specific feature? Hyperlink debugging sounds interesting for mouse aficionados, but I will probably not use it much for 2 reasons:
1) I prefer using the keyboard, and hyperlinks can only be activated by mouse
2) It still requires me to manually point to the method name "doRealStuff" in the scenario from comment 0. After a series of Step Over (F6), the mouse cursor is usually far away from the method name. If Step Into Selection (F9 in my workspace) would just do what I need, then my next debugging step would be just 1 keystroke away - unbeatably quick and convenient.
I would strongly prefer a mouseless solution. My patch is still applicable, works, and does not change anything for the original usage path of Step Into Selection, so I think you should just release it ;-).
Deferring. dup
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of bug 44101 *** (In reply to comment #5)
> I would strongly prefer a mouseless solution. My patch is still applicable, > works, and does not change anything for the original usage path of Step Into > Selection, so I think you should just release it ;-).
Wow. I'm very impressed with Mr. Keller actually offering a working patch. Why is this being deferred? Since it is a duplicate of a bug which has been deferred for 3-1/2 years, I hope Mr. Keller isn't looking for a quick resolution.
Darin, what's the reason for not using the suggested fix? Is the code not good enough or do you think this feature could cause harm to some users (I can't imagine why, since it only replaces an error condition with useful behavior)?
I can update the patch to HEAD if that would raise the chances of getting this feature (would have to copy StepIntoSelectionUtils#getMethod() back to StepIntoSelectionActionDelegate to avoid wrong behavior in StepIntoSelectionHyperlinkDetector). I have not had a chance to review the patch (or it's been a while). I think Mike said there was an issue when code was split over several lines? We can look at it again in 3.4. > I think Mike said there was an issue when code was split over several lines?
'Issue' or 'feature', that's the question;-). My approach only enters the next method invocation on the current line. IMO, it would become confusing if 'Step into Selection' would go further than the current line to find a target. I would argue that the 'Selection' means - the selected region, or if that's empty - the caret position, or if that's not in a method - the next method on the selected (current) line Yeah when I was playing with the patch it did not work over more than one line. In this case though I guess it comes down to how we want to define 'current line' do we want it to only be the current line of text or the current executable line....I felt that it should work for broken lines as well.
For example it should work for:
1. doSomething(getSomeText(), getSomeMoreText());
AND
2. doSomething(
getSomeText(), getSomeMoreText()
);
In both cases if I have the caret in the method call getSomeMoreText() I should be able to step into doSomething()
Just my two cents though... > In both cases if I have the caret in the method call getSomeMoreText() I should > be able to step into doSomething()
That could make sense if "Step into Outermost Method Invocation" was a separate command. We could discuss that approach, but I find the extension of "Step into Selection" by far more elegant (and it also saves a command/action/keybinding/...).
If you accept this solution, then the only case I see where it does not work with broken lines is this:
3. before(); | doSomething(getSomeText(), getSomeMoreText());
If you manually put the caret into the line between 'before' and 'doSomething' (note that the debugger never puts the caret to that line!), then my patch does not find 'doSomething'. Arguments for this behavior are comment 12 and predictably good performance, since the scanner does not potentially spend a lot of time scanning all following lines for a possible target.
Reopening, since this is in fact not a dup of bug 44101. Bug 44101 is about changing the default behavior of "Step Into", but this bug wants "Step Into Outermost" or an enhanced "Step Into Selection". (I disagree with bug 44101, since I think "Step Into" should not depend on the caret position but always step into the next method that the VM enters.) This feature is at odds with bug 44067. This feature requests that "step into selection" should step into the outermost method (or caret position method) when there is no selection. Bug 44067 suggests that step into selection should just perform a "step into".
Jerome, what are your feelings on this? *** Bug 44067 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** OK, Jerome's request is the same as this - he wants to step into the next method. +1 for this feature. Created attachment 73414 Patch (updated to HEAD) Tested and applied patch. It does not change the default behavior of step into selection but catches one single edge case where it can step into the first method to the right of the current caret position. Maybe it should have been called step into next selected method?
please verify Curtis W
see StepIntoSelectionActionDelegate and StepIntoSelectionUtils
Thanks for the patch Markus Verified

Bug.Summery: [IDE] Copy, Delete, Paste doens't work
Bug.WithStack:
If you select a file, copy it, delete it, and then try to paste it back, the copy fails and says resource does not exist on disk.
I think this is different than the way most windows apps work with copy/cut/paste. Is this in the resource navigator or package explorer?
The paste action should be checking whether the source file still exists before trying to copy it. There are two things that could be done: i) the paste action is a no-op if the source file does not exist anymore; ii) the paste action uses the most recent entry (if any) for that file's history and copy its contents to the new file (which seems to do what the originator expected). Resource explorer. Actually I am wrong. I tested on windows and if you copy, delete and try to paste it gives a similar error.

Bug.Summery: Show a more detailed name for profiling agents
Bug.WithStack: Currently, the profiling monitor shows agent labels such as "<monitoring> Profiling (11/25/04 7:05:44 PM)". When you attach to a few agents at the same time (both of type "Profiler"), you get identical entries and have no way to distinguish them. We need a more detailed label here. One possibility is to use the full agent name. Bug.Summery: Nested Scroller Drawing Error on OS X
Bug.WithStack:
Whenever a scrollable object (e.g. List) is drawn on a ScrolledComposite, the List box will erroneously scroll the screen area out to the edge of the current window instead of scrolling within its container object.
Sample code and screen shots to follow. Created attachment 16147 Screen shot of Erroneous OS X Window Created attachment 16148 Screen shot of Valid Dialog Window Created attachment 16149 TestDialog - code to produce error on OS X
This sample dialog will cause the error on OS X. Yikes! Chrix to investigate with help as necessary from SSQ. Oh ya, this is the "Mac introduced in 1984 and still doesn't clip widgets properly in 2005". This could be fixed if we move to HIView.

Bug.Summery: persist/restore which editor was opened by the debugger
Bug.WithStack: With the fix to bug 35400, the debug UI no longer persists/restores which editor(s) it opened in which windows. I could not find a way to uniquely identify an editor within a window. (It used to work, since the launch view persisted the index of the editor it opened, and did not have to identify the window that the editor was in). No intention to fix.

I could not find a way to uniquely identify an editor within a window. (It used to work, since the launch view persisted the index of the editor it opened, and did not have to identify the window that the editor was in). No intention to fix.

Bug.Summery: No console attached to debug process for IO

Lines.Line: (1) you start eclipse with DISPLAY environment set
(2) When launching the program you set the DISPLAY environment.

Bug.WithStack:
If the summary is unclear, here is the situation:
I attempt to complete the CDT debug tutorial, but cannot give input for the "cin" statement, thus not being able to step through interactive command-line code. There are many ways to resolve this, such as allowing a custom launch commands or just attaching to the "console" window like when merely running the executable.
I am not sure if this matters if the program to be debugged is an X11 graphical app or regular Carbon/ Cocoa gui app. Perhaps I can test that later. I tried building/running a simple QT (gui) program and got "<testProgName>: cannot connect to X server". X11 is installed, however, so I figured the running Env was lacked something. After setting DISPLAY to 0:0 in the Run... Environment tab I was able to successfully run the graphical QT app both in "Run" and "Debug".
In doing this I discovered a slight flaw in the "step return" command in that it will not appropriately find files outside of the project working directory. For instance, I stepped into a QT library routine and Eclipse asked for the directory where this file lives (C/C++ File Editor... Source not found. You can attach a new source...) because "<some relative path that looks correct if used from the root of the project directory and not from eclipse's default workspace>" didn't work. > I tried building/running a simple QT (gui) program and got "<testProgName>: > cannot connect to X > server". X11 is installed, however, so I figured the running Env was lacked > something. After setting > DISPLAY to 0:0 in the Run... Environment tab I was able to successfully run > the graphical QT app both in > "Run" and "Debug".
Yes that is the correct way to do it. You must specified to the Xlib library which display to use, Unless : (1) you start eclipse with DISPLAY environment set (2) When launching the program you set the DISPLAY environment.
(1) is simpler since for new launch it will automatically inherit the Eclipse environment.
> In doing this I discovered a slight flaw in the "step return" command in that it will not appropriately find > files outside of the project working directory
That is still correct in this a limitatio of Eclipse/CDT, but you can add where the external sources are located in the source locator of the launch.
If you still have problem with it the source locator please make a new PR so we can deal with it.

Bug.Summery: Mac binary not recognized

Bug.WithOutStack: After building, the mac binary is not recognized as an executable. However, if the path and name is given manually (with no "Qualifications) it will run. It is in CDT 2.1.

Bug.Summery: Output of debugger and program mixes and appers in Eclipse console
Bug.WithStack:
Eclipse version - 3.0.1 + CDT version - 2.0.2
When I debug a C/C++ program from Eclipse, the output of gdb gets mixed up with the output of program [in Eclipse console]. It's extremely painful to find the output of the program from the console. I guess the o/p of gdb and that of program are re-directed to the same stream ? Though pin console filters the gdb's responses, I would like to have the o/p of gdb in some other console so that I don't miss any of them ;-)
- Ragav. > I guess the o/p of gdb and that of program are re-directed to the same stream ? No, the outputs of gdb and program are two separate streams.
As far as I understand you are mistaking the Console view and consoles. Each project in the Debug view has accosiated console. When a project is selected the Console view displays the console associated with it. When a console is not pinned the Console view displays the console with latest output. That's why you probably have an impression that output is mixed. Thanks for the clarification Mikhail. Well how can I separate the o/p of the debugger from that of the program and see the o/p of the program [alone] in the Console window.
This problem is not occuring when I debug a Java program. Why should CDT behave like this ? Is this the intended behavior ?
>Well how can I separate the o/p of the >debugger from that of the program and see the o/p of the program [alone] in >the Console window.
The output is NOT mixed. The whole Eclipse debug framework is driven by the selection in the Debug view. Each debug session is presented by the set fo targets and processes. Each process has a console associated with it. To see the output of a process select it in the Debug view. Make sure that your console is not pinned. A regular CDT debug session has two processes. The first one represents the program being debugged. Another process is associated with the underlying debugger - gdb. To see the output of any of these processes simple select it in the Debug view. If you don't want the Console view to switch to another output pin it by using the "Pin console" button.
>This problem is not occuring when I debug a Java program. Because when you debug a Java program you have one process (Java VM) that acts as a debugger and a debuggee as well.
>Why should CDT behave like this ? Is this the intended behavior ? In CDT many people use the gdb console to drive the debugger. More on this issue see https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=57602 and https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=69425.
Marking as INVALID.

I guess the o/p of gdb and that of program are re-directed to the same stream ? Though pin console filters the gdb's responses, I would like to have the o/p of gdb in some other console so that I don't miss any of them ;-)
- Ragav. > I guess the o/p of gdb and that of program are re-directed to the same stream ? No, the outputs of gdb and program are two separate streams.
As far as I understand you are mistaking the Console view and consoles. Each project in the Debug view has accosiated console. When a project is selected the Console view displays the console associated with it. When a console is not pinned the Console view displays the console with latest output. That's why you probably have an impression that output is mixed. Thanks for the clarification Mikhail. Well how can I separate the o/p of the debugger from that of the program and see the o/p of the program [alone] in the Console window.
This problem is not occuring when I debug a Java program. Why should CDT behave like this ? Is this the intended behavior ?
>Well how can I separate the o/p of the >debugger from that of the program and see the o/p of the program [alone] in >the Console window.
The output is NOT mixed. The whole Eclipse debug framework is driven by the selection in the Debug view. Each debug session is presented by the set fo targets and processes. Each process has a console associated with it. To see the output of a process select it in the Debug view. Make sure that your console is not pinned. A regular CDT debug session has two processes. The first one represents the program being debugged. Another process is associated with the underlying debugger - gdb. To see the output of any of these processes simple select it in the Debug view. If you don't want the Console view to switch to another output pin it by using the "Pin console" button.
>This problem is not occuring when I debug a Java program. Because when you debug a Java program you have one process (Java VM) that acts as a debugger and a debuggee as well.
>Why should CDT behave like this ? Is this the intended behavior ? In CDT many people use the gdb console to drive the debugger. More on this issue see https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=57602 and https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=69425.
Marking as INVALID.

Bug.Summery: new feature: find overwriting classes
Bug.WithStack:
hello,
there is currently a feature which displays that a method is overriding a method of a super class or interface. This can be done in the overview and/or vertical ruler. What would also be very interesting is the opposite. Sometimes it would be helpful to know if this method you're working on is overridden by some other class in the project/workspace. If it is not possible to have an annotation in some of the ruler a search option would be very nice. Something like "search overriding classes in project/workspace".
regards,
matthias hanisch The problem is of course performance. Getting all subtypes can take minutes e.g. for Object.
What we offer here is CTRL+T on the method that shows you all methods that override the given method As of now 'LATER' and 'REMIND' resolutions are no longer supported. Please reopen this bug if it is still valid for you.

Bug.Summery: [launching] Unable to "share" shared launch configuration
Bug.WithStack:
I've found a problem with sharing launch configurations. Well, it's mainly a ClearCase problem but the ClearCase people were telling us that they are unable to fix it because it would require to much changes.
ClearCase limits the line legth of text files (also xml files) to 8000 characters or so. Now I have a shared launch configuration which has a line length of 19850 characters. That's too much for ClearCase. I guess they hard coded the limit is several places. That's why they are unable to fix it.
The problematic element is a org.eclipse.debug.core.source_locator_memento stringAttribute. The value seems to contain encoded xml. The encoding is too restrictive. It even encodes line breaks.
<stringAttribute key="org.eclipse.debug.core.source_locator_memento" value="<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<sourceLookupDirector>
....
so, now I have a shared launch configuration but can't share it. Is there a way to change this to avoid long lines? John, do you have any insight on this, and what other SDK components do to live with this limitation? This is my first exposure to this requirement (so I don't have any special insight) Can the file just be marked binary, so that there are no "lines" in it to worry about?
When we've run into cases where know we need to store text containing line separators or other directly user-influenced text, we use a child node instead of an attribute value. Putting the text into a CDATA node and placing that inside of a child element tends to save us from having to worry about escaping any characters aside from the CDATA ending sequence, "]]>".
<stringAttribute key="org.eclipse.debug.core.source_locator_memento" value="<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<sourceLookupDirector>
....
becomes:
<stringAttribute key="org.eclipse.debug.core.source_locator_memento"> <value> <![CDATA[<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <sourceLookupDirector> .... ]]> </value> </stringAttribute>
Well, of course this is possible but then you'll loose all the nice merge features of ClearCase and, in our environment only _the_ admin can change a file type. Regulare users (developers) don't have the necessary permissions. Nothing planned for 3.1 As of now 'LATER' and 'REMIND' resolutions are no longer supported. Please reopen this bug if it is still valid for you.

Bug.Summery: [IProblem] [Templates] Problem when parsing template variable
[Parser] Macros in class declaration
GTK Display performance optimization

Lines.Line: 1. Display.putGdkEvents() which takes 4% of total execution time is avoided
2. Display.eventProc() and Display.idleProc() are called only 3 200 times in
comparison with current CVS where Display.eventProc() is called 51 000 times
3. Display.eventProc() and Display.idleProc() take only 12% of execution time
in comparison with current CSV where Display.eventProc() takes 14% of execution

Bug.WithStack:
This PR is a continuation of the bug #77812. The problem is that SWT intensively filters GDK events and then puts them back into OS. Patch suggested in the bug #77812 was not suitable due to Java event queue is not visible to GTK.
Patch proposed in this PR solves this problem using GTK idle source which is added to main context if Java has deferred GDK events.
I am going to attach the patch in the next post. Created attachment 16158 Display patch Created attachment 16159 Native library for patch
Native library which implements function from OS1 class. Wow. This fix is really complicated. Dispatch the events from a higher priority idle handler. This will take a long time to decode and understand all of the ramifications of this.
The question I have for you is, "Is the fix still necessary?". Given that the queue now grows faster and Eclipse no longer causes deferred events to happen in the open editor benchmark. Given that the idea actually works, the trade off here is the complexity of understanding and maintainability of the code. If GTK changes anything in this area, we are exposed.
My preference would be to keep this idea in our back pocket for now. I checked this on scenario when 30 Java editors are opened at once. This fix is still necessary
Here are the reasons
1. Display.putGdkEvents() which takes 4% of total execution time is avoided 2. Display.eventProc() and Display.idleProc() are called only 3 200 times in comparison with current CVS where Display.eventProc() is called 51 000 times 3. Display.eventProc() and Display.idleProc() take only 12% of execution time in comparison with current CSV where Display.eventProc() takes 14% of execution time
So proposed solution is 6% faster than current.
"the trade off here is the complexity of understanding and maintainability of the code"
Saying that words you can reject any idea which makes things slightly different. A lot of thing in GTK is done using contribution into main loop via idle handlers. Concept of main loop and recursive iterations is a base for GTK.
"If GTK changes anything in this area, we are exposed."
If GTK changes anything in ANY area, we are exposed. GTK has API and main loops and contexts are the part of GTK API. For example if GTK changes the way it stores widget in GDK window so gdk_window_get_user_data is not longer valid we will need to rewrite our code also.
Code that keeps the events in the operating system queue is more likely to keep working than code that keeps them in a private queue and tries to feed them back to GTK at the right time in an idle handler. It is exactly because GTK does so much work in the idle handlers that I am afraid of this.
There is a big difference between GTK changing gdk_window_get_user_data() and causing us to fail and GTK changing the way events are dispatched, the idle handling etc. In the former case, we will GP. GTK is unlikely to make this change but, it they do we are dead. However, GTK is lible to play with any of the code that implements the event loop and idle handling, to fix a bug or optimize it etc. In this case, we are likely to break in subtle ways and not know why.
Given that the performance improvement is only 6% (an improvement by the way that we would take if the approach were less dangerous), the thinking right now is not to attempt this fix.
Other than opening the 30 editors (a case that Eclipse is supposed to have fixed), is there another place where this pattern occurs? I think this affects any code which waits for clipboard content I'm sorry but the changes are too dangerous. We WONTFIX this.

Bug.Summery: A bug in Thumbnail.ThumbnailUpdater
Bug.WithStack:
There is a bug in ThumbnailUpdater. It occurs when the source figure is moving. in Thumbnail.ThumbnailUpdater.start() the thumbnailGraphics is translated: thumbnailGraphics.translate(sourceFigure.getBounds().getLocation().negate());
There is silently assumed that source figure is not moving. But is the source figure is moving and ThumbnailUpdater is running, the method run() again asks for a source figure location: org.eclipse.draw2d.geometry.Point p = sourceFigure.getBounds().getLocation(); and this can be different.
I recommend to delete a line that translates thumbnailGraphics in the method start() and add it into a method run(). I will attach an example where we can see the effect of this bug and also my proposal - code change. Created attachment 16160 Thumbnail bug demo
A test code. Created attachment 16161 Patch proposal (Thumbnail.java)
A proposed patch. Changes in the code are marked by a tag: TODO 79542 I forgot to describe how to see a bug effect in the test code: Run the text and drag a scroll bar. The thumbnail is not redrawing correctly. Created attachment 83071 BrokenThumbnailExample
I took the code from the provided demo and patched it into the ThumbNailExample in draw2d examples. I can confirm that the text is missing from the thumbnail. Interesting that if we add 5 sets of figures (i = 5) the text appears in the thumbnail. Other values (i = 10) cause the text to not be in the thumbnail.
The provided patch does not fix the issue, so I have obsoleted it. Created attachment 123955 Thumbnails updater now checks to see whether the source figure is moving before it tries to repaint it Reassigned back to gef-inbox, also resetting target milestone, which has long passed.
Bug.WithOutStack:
There is a bug in ThumbnailUpdater. It occurs when the source figure is moving. in Thumbnail.ThumbnailUpdater.start() the thumbnailGraphics is translated: thumbnailGraphics.translate(sourceFigure.getBounds().getLocation().negate());

I recommend to delete a line that translates thumbnailGraphics in the method start() and add it into a method run(). I will attach an example where we can see the effect of this bug and also my proposal - code change. Created attachment 16160 Thumbnail bug demo
A test code. Created attachment 16161 Patch proposal (Thumbnail.java)

I took the code from the provided demo and patched it into the ThumbNailExample in draw2d examples. I can confirm that the text is missing from the thumbnail. Interesting that if we add 5 sets of figures (i = 5) the text appears in the thumbnail. Other values (i = 10) cause the text to not be in the thumbnail.
The provided patch does not fix the issue, so I have obsoleted it. Created attachment 123955 Thumbnails updater now checks to see whether the source figure is moving before it tries to repaint it Reassigned back to gef-inbox, also resetting target milestone, which has long passed.

Bug.Summery: [Preferences] Preference page for Code Formatter resizes improperly.
Bug.WithStack: If you go to the preference page for the code formatter and then resize it so that you can better see the preview of the formatted code, both the left and right portions of the formatter page consume horizontal space. The left side should NOT be set to grab excess horizontal space but instead the preview pane should grab all of that space. Not so easy. This is managed by the SashForm, and to reimplement that is not trivial. The advantage of the current solution is that it is helpful when the left side uses a bigger font and is not fully visible.
Bug.WithOutStack: If you go to the preference page for the code formatter and then resize it so that you can better see the preview of the formatted code, both the left and right portions of the formatter page consume horizontal space. The left side should NOT be set to grab excess horizontal space but instead the preview pane should grab all of that space. Not so easy. This is managed by the SashForm, and to reimplement that is not trivial. The advantage of the current solution is that it is helpful when the left side uses a bigger font and is not fully visible.

Bug.Summery: ITypeBinding#isEqualTo(..) does not compare type arguments
Eclipse vs Sun JDK: different class files from the same source code
Bug.WithStack:
Compile the source code below in Eclipse and run it. Do the same using Sun JDK (1.4.1 or 1.5). The results are different. The problem is connected with +' ': Eclipse treats it as ' ' but Sun JDK converts that space into 32 (+' ' => + (int) ' ' => +32 => 32) (which IMHO is correct).
PS. I'm not sure if I picked the proper product (JDT)...
The source code:
public class CharIntTest { /** * Eclipse value: " " * JDK value: "32" */ public static String C = "" + +' '; /** * Eclipse value: "32" * JDK value: "32" */ public static String I = "" + +32;
public static void main(String[] args) { System.out.println(C); System.out.println(I); } } I will investigate. This is a bug with the computation of a compile-time constant with an unary expression. If (+' ') is replaced with (' '), then the Eclipse compiler behaves well. I am not sure why +' ' would be treated as a char. I will check the JLS. Created attachment 16176 Apply on HEAD We can also get rid of the operator parameter in the compute constant methods. Created attachment 16177 Apply on HEAD
New patch. Apply on the jdt/core project. Created attachment 16178 Apply on jdt.core.test.compiler Fixed and released in HEAD. Regression test added. Verified (in I20041214-2000) that the provided test case has the following output when compiled with Eclipse: 32 32
Bug.WithOutStack:
Compile the source code below in Eclipse and run it. Do the same using Sun JDK (1.4.1 or 1.5). The results are different. The problem is connected with +' ': Eclipse treats it as ' ' but Sun JDK converts that space into 32 (+' ' => + (int) ' ' => +32 => 32) (which IMHO is correct).
PS. I'm not sure if I picked the proper product (JDT)...
The source code:
public class CharIntTest { /** * Eclipse value: " " * JDK value: "32" */ public static String C = "" + +' '; /** * Eclipse value: "32" * JDK value: "32" */ public static String I = "" + +32;
public static void main(String[] args) { System.out.println(C); System.out.println(I); } } I will investigate. This is a bug with the computation of a compile-time constant with an unary expression. If (+' ') is replaced with (' '), then the Eclipse compiler behaves well. I am not sure why +' ' would be treated as a char. I will check the JLS. Created attachment 16176 Apply on HEAD We can also get rid of the operator parameter in the compute constant methods. Created attachment 16177 Apply on HEAD
New patch. Apply on the jdt/core project. Created attachment 16178 Apply on jdt.core.test.compiler Fixed and released in HEAD. Regression test added. Verified (in I20041214-2000) that the provided test case has the following output when compiled with Eclipse: 32 32

Lines.Line: - Generate a test failure in a comparison using assertEqualString (e.g.
- Double-clicking on test failure in junit view opens Result Comparison viewer
- Try to close the dialog using system close button (upper right)

- Second clock on system close button actually closes the viewer

Bug.Summery: [Viewers] Wrong SelectionChangedEvent when calling TreeViewer.setSorter
[format] Align fields in columns and anonymous classes
CVS Resource History View does not show history of selected file
Bug.WithStack:
Hi,
Reproduce as follows: -Right-click on a file -Team/Show in Resource History -Resource History view opens and shows no history for the file.
Same actions in Version: 3.0.0 Build id: 200403261517 result in the correct result in the CVS Resource History View.
Thanks, Jeroen. This works for me in the latest integration build and I don't remember any changes between 3.0 and 3.0.1 in this area. What server version are you using? Is there anything in the error log? If not, can you follow the steps at this URL to get a trace of what the sever is sending?:
http://dev.eclipse.org/viewcvs/index.cgi/%7Echeckout%7E/platform-vcm- home/docs/online/cvs_features2.0/cvs-faq.html#misc_0 Server version: CVSNT 2.0.34 No log.

However, most functionality is available. null] CMD> cvs log "GlobalObjectStorage.java" Directory . d:/cvsrepo/Amaris/PlexBaseClasses/plexservlet Entry /GlobalObjectStorage.java/1.7/// Is-modified GlobalObjectStorage.java Argument GlobalObjectStorage.java Directory . d:/cvsrepo/Amaris/PlexBaseClasses/plexservlet log M M RCS file: D:/cvsrepo/Amaris/PlexBaseClasses/plexservlet/GlobalObjectStorage.java,v M Working file: GlobalObjectStorage.java M head: 1.7 M branch: M locks: strict M access list: M symbolic names: M keyword substitution: kv M total revisions: 7; selected revisions: 7 M description: M ---------------------------- M revision 1.7 M date: 2004/11/19 11:21:53; author: DCORLUY; state: Exp; lines: +4 -0; kopt: kv; commitid: 1fc419dd7510000; M *** empty log message *** M ---------------------------- M revision 1.6 M date: 2004/11/19 10:23:25; author: JDVos; state: Exp; lines: +167 -244; kopt: kv; commitid: ad4419dc99d0000; M formatting en renaming M ---------------------------- M revision 1.5 M date: 2004/11/17 22:45:11; author: DCORLUY; state: Exp; lines: +15 -7; kopt: kv; commitid: 7a0419bd4750000; M bug fixes rond save document & response M ---------------------------- M revision 1.4 M date: 2004/11/17 15:06:16; author: DCORLUY; state: Exp; lines: +2 -6; kopt: kv; commitid: c58419b68e70000; M Foutje op objecten met 1 ID. M ---------------------------- M revision 1.3 M date: 2004/11/16 09:01:48; author: DCORLUY; state: Exp; lines: +48 -43; kopt: kv; commitid: 96c4199c1fb0000; M Eigen object store M ---------------------------- M revision 1.2 M date: 2004/11/10 12:22:59; author: DCORLUY; state: Exp; lines: +64 -13; kopt: kv; commitid: a2c419208230000; M Additional synchronisation for all operation on global object store. M Java doc info M ---------------------------- M revision 1.1 M date: 2004/11/04 08:33:34; author: JDVos; state: Exp; kopt: kv; commitid:bf04189e95d0000; M initial M ============================================================================= ok RESULT> Status OK: org.eclipse.team.cvs.core code=0 ok null That is an unsupported version of CVSNT. However, it will still work for the most part. You need to make sure that the case you use for your repository path matches that which the server returns. You used "d:\..." where the server returns "D:\..." so you'll need to create your repository path using a capital "D". Eclipse doesn't differentiate between CVSNT and the cvshome.org CVS and assumes that paths are case sensitive. CVSNT is communicating with Eclipse with the assumption that paths (or at least drive letters) are not case sensitive.
Check this link for more details on server compatibility issues.
http://dev.eclipse.org/viewcvs/index.cgi/%7Echeckout%7E/platform-vcm- home/docs/online/html-cvs/cvs-compatibility.html

Eclipse tracing: I LOVE YOU Valid-responses ok error M E Checked-in Valid-requests Template Set-sticky MT Clear-static-directory Module-expansion Set-static-directory Clear-sticky New- entry Merged Removed Updated Remove-entry Update-existing Copy-file Created Notified Mod-time valid-requests Valid-requests Root Valid-responses valid-requests Directory Max-dotdot Static- directory Sticky Entry EntryExtra Kopt Checkin-time Modified Is-modified UseUnchanged Unchanged Notify NotifyUser Questionable Case Utf8 Argument Argumentx Globa l_option Gzip-stream wrapper-sendme-rcsOptions Set expand-modules ci co chown setowner setperm chacl setacl listperm lsacl setpass passwd update diff log rlog add remove update-patches status ls rdiff tag rtag import admin export history re lease watch-on watch-off watch-add watch-remove watchers editors init annotate rannotate noop version Rootless-stream-modification Kerberos-encrypt Gssapi- encrypt Protocol-encrypt Gssapi-authenticate Protocol-authenticate read-cvsrc read-cvsrc2 read-cvsignore read-cvswrappers Error-If-Reader Valid- RcsOptions ok Root d:/cvsrepo CMD> cvs version version M Concurrent Versions System (CVSNT) 2.0.34 (client/server) ok RESULT> Status WARNING: org.eclipse.team.cvs.core code=1 The following warnings were reported while performing the "cvs version" command. null children=[Status WARNING: org.eclipse.team.cvs.core code=-21 Host 'how1' is running CVS NT (versi on 2.0.34) which is not fully supported. However, most functionality is available. null] CMD> cvs log "GlobalObjectStorage.java" Directory . d:/cvsrepo/Amaris/PlexBaseClasses/plexservlet Entry /GlobalObjectStorage.java/1.7/// Is-modified GlobalObjectStorage.java Argument GlobalObjectStorage.java Directory . d:/cvsrepo/Amaris/PlexBaseClasses/plexservlet log M M RCS file: D:/cvsrepo/Amaris/PlexBaseClasses/plexservlet/GlobalObjectStorage.java,v M Working file: GlobalObjectStorage.java M head: 1.7 M branch: M locks: strict M access list: M symbolic names: M keyword substitution: kv M total revisions: 7; selected revisions: 7 M description: M ---------------------------- M revision 1.7 M date: 2004/11/19 11:21:53; author: DCORLUY; state: Exp; lines: +4 -0; kopt: kv; commitid: 1fc419dd7510000; M *** empty log message *** M ---------------------------- M revision 1.6 M date: 2004/11/19 10:23:25; author: JDVos; state: Exp; lines: +167 -244; kopt: kv; commitid: ad4419dc99d0000; M formatting en renaming M ---------------------------- M revision 1.5 M date: 2004/11/17 22:45:11; author: DCORLUY; state: Exp; lines: +15 -7; kopt: kv; commitid: 7a0419bd4750000; M bug fixes rond save document & response M ---------------------------- M revision 1.4 M date: 2004/11/17 15:06:16; author: DCORLUY; state: Exp; lines: +2 -6; kopt: kv; commitid: c58419b68e70000; M Foutje op objecten met 1 ID. M ---------------------------- M revision 1.3 M date: 2004/11/16 09:01:48; author: DCORLUY; state: Exp; lines: +48 -43; kopt: kv; commitid: 96c4199c1fb0000; M Eigen object store M ---------------------------- M revision 1.2 M date: 2004/11/10 12:22:59; author: DCORLUY; state: Exp; lines: +64 -13; kopt: kv; commitid: a2c419208230000; M Additional synchronisation for all operation on global object store. M Java doc info M ---------------------------- M revision 1.1 M date: 2004/11/04 08:33:34; author: JDVos; state: Exp; kopt: kv; commitid:bf04189e95d0000; M initial M ============================================================================= ok RESULT> Status OK: org.eclipse.team.cvs.core code=0 ok null That is an unsupported version of CVSNT. However, it will still work for the most part. You need to make sure that the case you use for your repository path matches that which the server returns. You used "d:\..." where the server returns "D:\..." so you'll need to create your repository path using a capital "D". Eclipse doesn't differentiate between CVSNT and the cvshome.org CVS and assumes that paths are case sensitive. CVSNT is communicating with Eclipse with the assumption that paths (or at least drive letters) are not case sensitive.
Check this link for more details on server compatibility issues.
http://dev.eclipse.org/viewcvs/index.cgi/%7Echeckout%7E/platform-vcm- home/docs/online/html-cvs/cvs-compatibility.html

Bug.Summery: Function Folding not working with win32-API program
outline view not updated correctly after refactoring
Bug.WithStack:
The outline view does not get updated correctly after refactoring(renaming) a member variable.
I refactored a member variable fields into fieldPanel. After refactoring the outline view show both the member variable with the old name (fields) and with the new name (fieldPanel) see the screenshot.
My Configuration: ================= VE Version: 1.0.1.1 Build Id: 200410221351
Eclipse Version: 3.1.0 Build Id: 200408122000
EMF Version: 2.1.0 Build Id: 200410141127 Created attachment 16162 Screenshot of the outline update bug If the visual editor is reopend for the file the outline view gets updated correctly. That is actually a JDT problem. That isn't our view. Though it could be the way we are doing the change.
Since you are at 3.1 it may be a problem that was just added with them. It works for us at 3.0.x. Could you try something please? Bring up your class with the straight java editor, not the VE. Then from the text editor, select the field, do ctrl+1, then select "rename in file" and rename the field. See if the outline view is now bad. That is basically what we use under the covers. This works in VE 1.1 closing

Bug.Summery: Error from server that can be ignored
Bug.WithStack:
For some reason fiji is reporting this error:
: cvs server: cannot open /root/.cvsignore: Permission denied
For one, we should see how to configure fiji such that it doesn't give this error. Also, it does not affect the operation so we need to handle it more gracefully. We used to only fail when the command returned error but we seem to be failing now in more cases. Fixed in HEAD and server configured properly.
Bug.WithOutStack:
For some reason fiji is reporting this error:
: cvs server: cannot open /root/.cvsignore: Permission denied
For one, we should see how to configure fiji such that it doesn't give this error. Also, it does not affect the operation so we need to handle it more gracefully. We used to only fail when the command returned error but we seem to be failing now in more cases. Fixed in HEAD and server configured properly.

Bug.Summery: Return in try-block disables catch-block if final-block is present
Bug.WithStack:
If in a try-catch-finally block, the catch block contains a (conditional) return statement, an exception thrown within the try-block will not be handled by the catch-block. Instead the finally block is entered an the exception is passed on.
In these cases the Exception Table contains "any"-entries, that occur befor those of the real catch-block.
A short example can be found here: http://www.inf.tu-dresden.de/~s7060674/temp/ajc_bug.zip Created attachment 16166 Minimal testcase to reproduce the bug Fixed by the work done for bug 78021 which ensures the exception table entries aren't damaged by weaving. Fix checked in - waiting for build. Fix available:
BUILD COMPLETE - build.429 Date of build: 01/11/2005 11:52:16 Time to build: 103 minutes 38 seconds Last changed: 01/11/2005 11:22:16 Last log entry: Fixes for 78021, 79554 - both to do with us breaking the exception table for a method on weaving *if* finally blocks are involved. Latest good AspectJ jar available at: download.eclipse.org/technology/ajdt/dev/aspectj-DEVELOPMENT.jar
Bug.WithOutStack:
If in a try-catch-finally block, the catch block contains a (conditional) return statement, an exception thrown within the try-block will not be handled by the catch-block. Instead the finally block is entered an the exception is passed on.
In these cases the Exception Table contains "any"-entries, that occur befor those of the real catch-block.
A short example can be found here: http://www.inf.tu-dresden.de/~s7060674/temp/ajc_bug.zip Created attachment 16166 Minimal testcase to reproduce the bug Fixed by the work done for bug 78021 which ensures the exception table entries aren't damaged by weaving. Fix checked in - waiting for build. Fix available:
BUILD COMPLETE - build.429 Date of build: 01/11/2005 11:52:16 Time to build: 103 minutes 38 seconds Last changed: 01/11/2005 11:22:16 Last log entry: Fixes for 78021, 79554 - both to do with us breaking the exception table for a method on weaving *if* finally blocks are involved. Latest good AspectJ jar available at: download.eclipse.org/technology/ajdt/dev/aspectj-DEVELOPMENT.jar
