It would be more useful to have the launcher detect that the eclipse executable is a symlink, and follow it to find the install directory. It was noted on IRC that using readlink() on /proc/self/exe might be the easiest way to fix this bug. This should be a pretty easy fix... Created attachment 31323 Patch
Here's a patch that users readlink() to adress the problem, updating the path to startup.jar and also the launcher executable itself. Could you look it over and let me know if this looks reasonable?
Thanks, Igor Created attachment 31329 Patch 2
I updated the patch to take out some debug statements and make the formatting conform to the style used in the code.
Igor Created attachment 34096 Patch with some fixes
Hi Billy,
I've uploaded a fixed up patch. We've been using this patch in FC for the past couple of months and it works well. Any news on commiting this? *** Bug 149432 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. *** Moving to equinox / fwk where launcher bug now belongs. Andrew, has this been fixed in the new launcher? Should it be fixed for 3.3? The new launcher does resolve symlinks, but it is more than one level. The use case at the beginning of this bug works.
However, looking in the patch itself, there seems to be a second use case that does not work: /usr/bin/eclipse -> /usr/share/eclipse3.3/eclipse /usr/share/eclipse3.3/eclipse -> /usr/lib/eclipse
Can someone from Redhat comment on this?
We actually don't use either case anymore. Right now we install eclipse to /usr/share/eclipse/ but for FHS compliance we can't have arch specificic binaries in /usr/share/. This includes the second case mentioned in comment #9 where there is a symlink from /usr/share/ to a binary in /usr/lib{,64}/.
To get around this problem, the eclipse binrary is patched to always load from /usr/share/eclipse/ and it is installed directly in /usr/bin/. I would like to make a patch that allows people to set a compile flag to choose an absolute path location for the launcher to load eclipse from but I haven't found the time yet.
As far as this bug is concerned, I think it should be closed and I can open a new one for the requested feature mentioned above. Cheers, Ben Unforturnately for me, Andrew Niefer's use case is exactly the reason I voted for this bug.
I (want to) have /usr/local/bin/eclipse pointing to /opt/eclipse/eclipse, where /opt/eclipse points to /opt/eclipse-SDK-3.2.1. (In reply to comment #11) > Unforturnately for me, Andrew Niefer's use case is exactly the reason I voted > for this bug. > > I (want to) have /usr/local/bin/eclipse pointing to /opt/eclipse/eclipse, where > /opt/eclipse points to /opt/eclipse-SDK-3.2.1.
OK sorry. I guess the bug should stay open for your use case :)
Johan, your case works. Comment #9 is slightly different, the executable is in a different location from the rest of the eclipse install.
Note that eclipse can run with the executable in another location, it just requires some arguments. Something like /usr/bin/eclipse --launcher.library /usr/lib/eclipse_1009.so -startup /usr/share/eclipse/plugins/org.eclipse.equinox.launcher_1.0.0.v2007.jar
Marking as fixed

Bug.Summery: [prefs] Preference initializer run after plugin class constructor
Bug.WithStack:
R3.0.1
From the RCP newsgroup, topic "When does AbstractUIPlugin" initialize preference?
Yes, after some tracing, the preferences are initialized lazily, when the Preferences object is first queried.
But you cannot query the Preferences object, for example in the BrowserPlugin constructor. initializeDefaultPluginPreferences() and initializePluginPreferences() are both deprecated, using preference initializer extension point to set default values turn out to be executed after the BrowserPlugin are fully loaded, compare to the case in initializeDefaultPluginPreferences() and initializePluginPreferences() which are called after the start(BundleContext context). This introduces problems where you need to check for certain value during the Plugin initialization.
Poking around some source codes, it turns out most ppl are loading the Preferences object and setting the default values in the start(BundleContext context) function, which solve my problem for now.
Thanks for the helps. When should the preference initializer be run? Existing code that relies on being able to obtain the values from within the constructor will no longer work if they move to initializers (with the recent changes, does it even work if they haven't moved)? If it's not reasonable to query prefs from the constructor, what should the behaviour be? Silent failure, exception, log entry?
Created attachment 16182 test plug-in
I'm not sure I understand the problem yet.
Attached is a test plug-in. It uses a preference initializer to initialize default preference values. It accesses the default preferences both in the constructor and in the #start method. Both times it gets the values that is expected. (the one that was set in the initializer) Does it also work if you go through the compatibility APIs?
I did not actually try this myself, just based it on what was being said in the newsgroup. If the test case works, then I suggest closing as WORKSFORME.
I'll have to look into it further. It might not work if you have:
public MyPlugin() { super(); getPluginPreferences(); }
In my example I was using:
public MyPlugin() { super(); new DefaultScope().getNode("my_id").get("foo", "bar"); }
Bug.WithOutStack:
R3.0.1
From the RCP newsgroup, topic "When does AbstractUIPlugin" initialize preference?
Yes, after some tracing, the preferences are initialized lazily, when the Preferences object is first queried.
But you cannot query the Preferences object, for example in the BrowserPlugin constructor. initializeDefaultPluginPreferences() and initializePluginPreferences() are both deprecated, using preference initializer extension point to set default values turn out to be executed after the BrowserPlugin are fully loaded, compare to the case in initializeDefaultPluginPreferences() and initializePluginPreferences() which are called after the start(BundleContext context). This introduces problems where you need to check for certain value during the Plugin initialization.
Poking around some source codes, it turns out most ppl are loading the Preferences object and setting the default values in the start(BundleContext context) function, which solve my problem for now.
Thanks for the helps. When should the preference initializer be run? Existing code that relies on being able to obtain the values from within the constructor will no longer work if they move to initializers (with the recent changes, does it even work if they haven't moved)? If it's not reasonable to query prefs from the constructor, what should the behaviour be? Silent failure, exception, log entry?

Bug.Summery: Schema documentation is shown in a tooltip in the plugin editor.
Bug.WithStack: Hovering over the label of any Extension element attribute in the PDE editor causes the documentation for that attribute to be shown in a tooltip. This does not work for attributes that have long documentation. Screencap forthcoming. Created attachment 16179 The tooltip in question. Certainly weird-looking. Aside: why aren't people using the special SWT manifest that pretties up their Eclipse on XP? My laptop runs at a low resolution and the manifest eats too many pixels. OK, let get this one off the table. Fixed by wraping the description before setting it as a tooltip. No more 1000 pixel-wide, one-sentence tooltips.
Bug.WithOutStack: Hovering over the label of any Extension element attribute in the PDE editor causes the documentation for that attribute to be shown in a tooltip. This does not work for attributes that have long documentation. Screencap forthcoming. Created attachment 16179 The tooltip in question. Certainly weird-looking. Aside: why aren't people using the special SWT manifest that pretties up their Eclipse on XP? My laptop runs at a low resolution and the manifest eats too many pixels. OK, let get this one off the table. Fixed by wraping the description before setting it as a tooltip. No more 1000 pixel-wide, one-sentence tooltips.

Bug.Summery: Changes to IPathEntry APIs
Bug.WithStack:
After long discussion with Vlad, we need to enhance the PathEntry framework. The rewrite involves:
- New method getResolvedEntries() on ITranslationUnit, ICContainer, ICProject
- Redefinition of ICProject.getResolvedEntries()
- New class ICResource
- New extension on IContainerEntry (IContainerEntry2) * getResolvedEntries(ICResource) * addListener() --> to allow the container to notify of changes.
- Changes to PathEntryManager: - No caching for getResolvedEntries(IResource) - Testing for IContainerEntry2, to provider back and forward compatibility.
- Updated the documentation 8-) This wrong is targetting CDT-3.0
Reassign to Dave for the first draft. Raised priority since I will need this soon to integrate with 'per file' SCD.
(In reply to comment #2) > Raised priority since I will need this soon to integrate with 'per file' SCD.
Vlad I commited the first part so you can have a quick look but the changed listener extension is still missing.
look at:
IPathEntryContainerExtension.java
There are 2 new methods CoreModel.getIncludeEntries(IPath path) CoreModel.getMacroEntries(IPath path)
The ScannerProvider been updated to use this instead. Ok the listener is in take a look and let me know. Allright Vlad, it is done. Some changes that you should know. We've remove the listener ont IPathEntryContainerExtension, the problem was the lifecycle. So a solution was proposed by dave, instead of calling the listener all you have to do is calling
CoreModel.pathEntryContainerUpdates( IPathEntryContainerExtension container, PatheEntryContainerChanged[] changes, IProgressMonitor monitor);
That's it on this side reassigning to you. Let me know of any problems Alain, I played with the code for several days now and found a problem. I will attach the patch with the changes I made. Basically, I made DiscoveredPathContainer to implement IPathEntryContainerExtension as well as IPathEntryContainer. Now the problem that I am seeing is this:
In case of per project profile the container returns all discovered entries through getEntries() call, as before. It will return appropriate entries for getIncludeEntries(IPath) and getMacroEntries(IPath).
In case of per file profile the container returns sum of discovered per file discovered entries so that include paths can be properly displayed in CView. The container returns resource specific include path and symbol entries for getIncludeEntries(IPath) and getMacroEntries(IPath) calls respecively.
The problem is in PathEntryManager.getIncludeEntries(ITranslationUnit) (and corresponding getMacroEntries() function). This function will first add all include paths from getResolvedEntries() and then the ones from container.getIncludeEntries(IPath). The result will contain the sum of resource specific path entries and the resolved ones (which I thought were only for displaying in CView). On the other hand, if the container (actually PerFileDiscoveredPathInfo) does not return any entries when getEntries() is called then PathEntryManager.getIncludeEntries(ITranslationUnit) will correctly return only resource specific path entries, but the Includes item in CView will be empty.
Please take a look in the code and let me know what we can do to resolve this problem. It may as well be that I did not do things the right way.
Thanks, Vmir Created attachment 18246 Zip with patches We see the problem ... Been having a discussion with Dave. Let me get back to you(this afternoon or tomorrow at the latest). > The problem is in PathEntryManager.getIncludeEntries(ITranslationUnit) (and > corresponding getMacroEntries() function). This function will first add all > include paths from getResolvedEntries() and then the ones from > container.getIncludeEntries(IPath).
Vlad, give it a try again: If the container is an instanceof IPathEntryContainerExtension, the entries should not be cache at all .. The container should be query. I think this is what we've agreed on.
Let me know of the result The enhancement has been implemented as a part of scanner cofiguration correctness feature for CDT 3.0.
Thanks Alain.

Bug.Summery: [1.5] APIs for disassembling 1.5 attributes need to be cleanup

Lines.Line: (a) The client may assume that null will be returned if the tag item is not X.
(b) The client must not call this method if the tag item is not X.
Since clients may implement this method, it's important to be clear what the
Jim, a) is doable for the IAnnotationComponentValue, but it is not doable for
the IConstantPoolEntry class where some methods don't return an object.
I will change the implementation to return null when the constant is not the

Bug.WithStack:
Some APIs that have been added to handle 1.5 atttributes need to be cleanup. Some names have changed in the latest JVM specs since 3.0. These API should not be used by clients yet as they are related to 1.5 code. Released first batch of changes. IAnnotation added getTypeName() IAnnotationComponentValue renamed getAttributeValue() into getAnnotationValue() getAttributeValue() has been deprecated and will be remove after 3.1M4 added char[] getEnumConstantName() added char[] getEnumConstantTypeName()
Jim,
Are these changes ok for you? These look fine. A more general question re: all these methods. There are a couple of ways to interpret "This is initialized only if the tag item is X.". (a) The client may assume that null will be returned if the tag item is not X. (b) The client must not call this method if the tag item is not X. Since clients may implement this method, it's important to be clear what the contract is. I'd suggest reading (a). Jim, a) is doable for the IAnnotationComponentValue, but it is not doable for the IConstantPoolEntry class where some methods don't return an object. I will change the implementation to return null when the constant is not the expected one for the IAnnotationComponentValue. Clarified API. Jim, please review them. IAnnotationComponentValue and IConstantPoolEntry. Specs as fine. Closing. Verified.

Bug.Summery: Need to update the default filter set
Bug.WithStack:
The default filter set should be augmented with the following filters:
db2* * EXCLUDE com.tivoli* * EXCLUDE
When the piAgent runs under WAS, too much unnecessary data is generated that falls into the 'db2*' and 'com.tivoli*' packages. When the piAgent runs under WAS, you should select WebSphere J2EE filter set, and the two fiters mentioned have contained.
The bug is invalid. As of TPTP 4.6.0, TPTP is in maintenance mode and focusing on improving quality by resolving relevant enhancements/defects and increasing test coverage through test creation, automation, Build Verification Tests (BVTs), and expanded run-time execution. As part of the TPTP Bugzilla housecleaning process (see http://wiki.eclipse.org/Bugzilla_Housecleaning_Processes), this enhancement/defect is verified/closed by the Project Lead since this enhancement/defect has been resolved and unverified for more than 1 year and considered to be fixed. If this enhancement/defect is still unresolved and reproducible in the latest TPTP release (http://www.eclipse.org/tptp/home/downloads/), please re-open.

Bug.Summery: Problems with icons in dependencies view
Bug.WithStack:
in the new dependencies view, fragments have the icons of plugins.
For example, open dependencies on org.eclipse.swt, you will see that org.eclipse.swt.win32 has the blue (plugin) icon, not the pink (fragment) icon. (Problem 1)
Now, focus on 'org.eclipse.swt.win32'. Go to the history pull down, you will notice that the swt.win32 icon now has a red X overlay. (Problem 2).
Problem 3: Launch eclipse where the plugins view would initially appear on a previously remembered input (e.g. the pde.ui plugin). You will see that the history icon is disabled. Now focus on 'ant.core' or something, the history will only contain ant.core, not pde.ui as well. When is it going to finish (the dependencies view bugs)? :-)
Thanks for finding these problems, and for releasing patches.
